sentence: Technology stocks declined this afternoon, with shares of tech companies in the S&P 500 posting a 0.5% retreat.

In company news, Westell Technologies ( WSTL ) slumped to a new, all-time low on Thursday after the networking and telephone equipment company reported improved fiscal Q4 non-GAAP earnings compared with the same quarter last year but still coming in a penny wider than the Street view.

Excluding one-time items, the company recorded an adjusted net loss of $2.62 million, or $0.04 per share, during the three months ended March 31, narrowing a year-earlier net loss of $5.45 million, or $0.09 per share but lagging the $0.03 per share non-GAAP net loss that analysts, on average, were expecting.
Revenue rose 12% over year-ago levels to $20.9 million, missing Wall Street estimates by around $1.9 million.
WSTL shares were down over 16% at 96 cents apiece, recovering somewhat from its new record low of 93 cents a share set earlier today.
(+) CRM, Adjusted Q1 EPS of $0.24 tops Capital IQ consensus by $0.01 per share.
Revenue climbs 28% from last year to $1.92 bln, also beating the $1.89 bln consensus.
(-) CDRB, Files for Chapter 7 bankruptcy liquidation.
Terminates proposed merger with Aegis Identity Software.
All board members and executive officers, including CEO Arben Kryeziu, resign.
